instruction: How were the machine-learning estimators trained and tested in the study investigating drone remote sensing for silage grass swards?
Output:
In the study investigating drone remote sensing for silage grass swards, the machine-learning estimators were trained and tested using reference measurements and independent test datasets. The reference measurements included fresh and dry biomass, as well as several quality parameters such as the digestibility of organic matter in dry matter (the D-value), neutral detergent fibre (NDF), indigestible neutral detergent fibre (iNDF), water-soluble carbohydrates (WSC), nitrogen concentration (Ncont) in dry matter (DM), and nitrogen uptake (NU). 

The machine-learning estimators were trained using the random forest (RF) and multiple linear regression (MLR) methods. The training process involved using the reference measurements to train the estimators to accurately estimate the parameters of interest. 

Once trained, the estimators were then tested using independent test datasets. These test datasets were separate from the training data and were used to evaluate the performance and accuracy of the estimators. The accuracy of the estimators was assessed by comparing the estimated values to the actual values obtained from the reference measurements. 

The study found that the best results for biomass estimation, nitrogen amount, and digestibility were obtained when using hyperspectral and 3D data, followed by the combination of multispectral and 3D data.
